comments:
in Eclipse 3.1 RC3, developed plug-ins using emf-sdo-xsd-SDK-I200506160200.zip
will run correctly if exported, but will fail if run under the PDE.

The problem does NOT occur if regressing to the previous emf build
emf-sdo-xsd-SDK-I200506091102.zip.

The error log is as follows:

This scenario works for me so it sounds like you have a dirty configuration. 
Have you been running with -clean when you change the installed plugins?  We've
switched from flat plugins to jarred plugins in this build, so that changes the
configuration much more than previous drivers.

This was a fresh installation of Eclipse 3.1 RC3 and the emf
emf-sdo-xsd-SDK-I200506160200.zip so clean is not an issue. However, just to be
sure that I am not dreaming I just now ERASED from my Eclipse installation the
emf build that works, installed emf-sdo-xsd-SDK-I200506160200.zip, started
Eclipse with -clean and the problem returned. Repeated this with the
emf-sdo-xsd-SDK-I200506091102.zip build and the problem disappeared.

It may help that I imported the emf plugins and fragments into my workspace
using the "Binary" option rather than "Binary with linked content". The linked
content version does not allow the export plugins correctly (this is a known bug
I think).

This was a fresh installation of Eclipse 3.1 RC3 and the emf
emf-sdo-xsd-SDK-I200506160200.zip so clean is not an issue. However, just to be
sure that I am not dreaming I just now ERASED from my Eclipse installation the
emf build that works, installed emf-sdo-xsd-SDK-I200506160200.zip, started
Eclipse with -clean and the problem returned. Repeated this with the
emf-sdo-xsd-SDK-I200506091102.zip build and the problem disappeared.

It may help that I imported the emf plugins and fragments into my workspace
using the "Binary" option rather than "Binary with linked content". The linked
content version does not allow the export plugins correctly (this is a known bug
I think).

Interesting problem.  What is going on here is that the MANIFEST.MF file created
by the import wizard doesn't do a  

Eclipse-AutoStart: true

which is recommended when the plugin defines a Plugin Class.  If you add it to
the end of the manifest file, everything will work fine.

I am transfering the bugzilla to PDE. To help them reproducing the problem:

1. Install a fresh Eclipse RC3

2. Download the EMF build
http://download.eclipse.org/tools/emf/downloads/drops/2.1.0/I200506160200/emf-sdo-xsd-SDK-I200506160200.zip

3. Unzip EMF on top of RC3 and start RC3

4. File->Import->External Plug-ins and Fragments

5. First Page: select "Binary Projects"

6. Second Page: Type *emf* and click "Add and finish the dialog

7. Launch a runtime workspace

8. In the runtime workspace do a File->New Project->Eclipse Modeling
Framework->EMF Project


==> You should be seeing an exception now


To fix the exception you need to add 

Eclipse-AutoStart: true

to the end of MANIFEST.MF of the following plugins

org.eclipse.emf.codegen
org.eclipse.emf.codegen.ecore
org.eclipse.emf.codegen.ecore.ui
org.eclipse.emf.codegen.ui
org.eclipse.emf.common
org.eclipse.emf.common.ui
org.eclipse.emf.ecore
org.eclipse.emf.ecore.edit
org.eclipse.emf.ecore.editor
org.eclipse.emf.ecore.sdo.doc
org.eclipse.emf.ecore.xmi
org.eclipse.emf.edit
org.eclipse.emf.edit.ui
org.eclipse.emf.importer
org.eclipse.emf.importer.ecore
org.eclipse.emf.importer.java
org.eclipse.emf.importer.rose

The "Import plugin as binary" facility is used by clients that want to see and
use the non-java resources available in plugins during development.  In EMF,
these resources are the ecore and gemodel files, that contain the model definition.

Our users have been using the "Import plugin as binary" facility for quite a
while and would expect it to be working in Eclipse 3.1.  If this bug is not
fixed, any imported plugin that requires the Eclipse-AutoStart attribute to be
set to true (which is the case of any plugin that provides a Plugin Class) will
not work in the runtime workbench.

when you do a binary import and the plugin is JARd and has a dot on its 
classpath (implicit or explicit), PDE modifies the bundle-classpath header to 
reference a JAR since we don't want to blow up all those classes in the 
project.

In the case of the EMF plugins, when we are reading the manifest.mf headers 
using the JRE manifest parser, the Eclipse-Autostart header is not being read 
by the parser, and that is why it is being lost when we are writing back the 
file.

When you do an import with source, everything works fine of course because we 
leave the manifest.mf file as-is.

This problem does not occur in any of the SDK plugins even though most, if not 
all, of them have Eclipse-Autostart as the last header.

Please double-check the manifest.mf for EMF to make sure they are not missing 
a trailing line break or something.

The JRE manifest parser is very terse.  The runtime's home-grown parser is a 
lot more forgiving.

Will move back to EMF to re-investigate their manifests.
cc myself to remain in the loop.

I just confirmed that the manifest.mf for the emf plugins as they appear in 
the build are missing a line break at the end.

The sdk plugins have a line break.

It appears that our build machine's CVS client truncates the last line of every
file.  We'll investigate further on Monday to find out why the platform doesn't
have this problem.  A workaround for us is to add two line feeds at the end of
all our MANIFEST.MF files.

We fixed the problem that was removing the extra line of our manifest files, so
EMF plugins will be imported fine.  Of course this doesn't address the fact that
requiring an extra line may not be a good design.

Special thanks to the PDE folks for helping to identify this problem.

The change is committed to CVS.
